alternatives.transcript: the television studio is a familiar setting for tobacco Institute spokesman Bill Dwyer car need wrath Walker merryman and an Browder take the tobacco industry's case to the public they present the cigarette manufacturers point of view to live and broadcast audiences throughout the country the spokesman's program is a face-to-face Communications effort which began in 1975 it's

look relations objective is to bring a seemingly closed subject back to the level of controversy in the Public's mind many of these opportunities are initiated by us since this program has been underway the spokesman have addressed hundreds of rotary Kiwanis and other service clubs they've also spoken before professional seminars business conventions academic forms and tobacco industry audiences these platform appearances generate interest among the news

media resulting in newspaper and magazine interviews as well as invitations to appear on Network and local broadcasts here build wire discusses the public smoking controversy with a member of Congress on The Today Show Stars when is there on a scientific work that demonstrates smoking is bad for you to the smoker or the non smoker I'm not talking about this mocha I'm the nonsmoker and this thing here Rings five times as much carbon monoxide into

my system the nonsmoker as into his system the smoking it brings 50 times more ammonia into my system the non smoker then to the smoker and it brings more cadmium that gets down and erodes the sacs in the lungs and cause causes emphysema and you prove that's hazardous congressman who are you scientists in able to do that yeah you are one school little bit of the evidence that right in your own backyard you know the study Finance not buy tobacco but by the American Lung Association found out that the nonsmoker would have to be in a crowd

good bar in Boston five have a lot of those involved will not let you go let me finish on this this is in the Journal of the New England medical society that the non smoker would have to be exposed for longer than 100 hours continuously to inhale the equivalent of a single filter cigarette now in a Boston bar any bar I think you could spend five days there's more likely to imperil your liver than your long walk a merry men and Connie drath also addressed this issue on local public affairs broadcast

yeah I got this man FrontRunner come back to yeah I think there are two issues that we ought to clear up a little bit first of all in regard to legislation I think we've seen an example here in the audience that the kind of voluntary approach that we as an industry would rather see followed certainly can work here's a gentleman who sets aside a specific portion of his restaurant for non-smokers and gives them a break all right everybody in this restaurant you said don't you know everybody in the actually a very tiny place so that's the only choice we had if we had lots of money to get the tent

sound off for not smoking or you pay the full Bill well that's fine I've got no problem with that if somebody wants to prohibit smoking entirely or set aside smoking and non-smoking sections if it works that's fine if it doesn't work the person who owns or rents or manages that facility or business ought to have the right to respond to the Democracy with the marketplace to respond to how people want to be served and I think that's the essential thing now this question of Rights

in a legal sense I don't think really exist I think the federal courts and the Supreme Court has spoken to that these I'm not by not allowing this kind of case to be presented to the Supreme Court this mulch not a matter of employment but I do and we have the assistant to the president of the tobacco Institute and her name is Connie draft Connie would you explain how you feel about this Paul we find it very regrettable that the New Jersey Public Health Council has decided to turn

it is a personal preference into a crime and we're talking about criminalizing those people who choose to smoke turning people who are normally law-abiding citizens into law Breakers because the regulations that they had promulgated have the force of law we object to this anti-smoking restriction for essentially three reasons number one this is a courtesy issue it's not an area where we need government control or intervention

certainly there are times and places where people should not smoke but we frankly believe that the majority of people who smoke in this country have the Good Sense the consideration the common decency to know where and when smoking is appropriate and where it's not appropriate they don't need the public health Council to dictate that for them secondly this is not a health issue it is a question of annoyance to some people on some occasions particularly when you don't have adequate ventilation

Congress the United States Congress the House of Representatives has looked into the question of smoking and its effects on non-smokers last September 18 eminent men and women of science from hospitals and universities all over the country came to present testimony all of them were unanimous in the Judgment that based on all of the evidence published so far Smoking may be bothersome annoying in certain public places but it is not a threat

to the health of the nonsmoker so therefore why do we need a law we promulgate laws generally to protect the public from a health hazard not simply an annoyance and thirdly we object because this law will be unenforceable that's not just our opinion the tobacco institute's that is also the opinion of the New Jersey Conference of Mayors and the policemen's benevolent Society who have voiced their opinion on several occasions that it's a distortion

in of public priorities to criminalize those who smoke that police officers have more important priorities like going after murders bank robbers and rapists not going out to collar smokers who might light up in a prohibited place thank you very much you're very well thanks we've got the two sides fairly well to living a turd of course there's a lot more exploration to be done and we'll do that in just a moment

the spokesman are often called upon to defend the industry's long-standing policy that smoking is not for kids and Browder makes the point clear in this interview people have heard the warning and they are continuing to smoke particularly women and teenage girls are smoking and higher and higher percentages well I think if we put things in the proper

spective as far as teenage girls are concerned we have to realize that teenage girls are doing a lot of things today that they have not previously done there certainly is an increased incidence of alcoholism among teenage females in our society promiscuity and many other things I don't I certainly do not believe that cigarette advertising encourages anyone to begin smoking I think advertising tends to divide the market among the

who are already smokers I as their smoker might be encouraged to switch from Brand a to Brandon be because of some advertisement but I don't think that I as a nonsmoker would be encouraged to begin smoking and for example even with teenagers We Believe now that the information that we're getting out is getting across and it's not just that blanket warning about smoking is dangerous to you it's what specifically does that mean to me as an individual and it's important also to think in terms of countering

while smoking in cigarette products are not advertised on television anymore there's 800 million dollars a year roughly spent on promoting and advertising cigarettes it's an enormous volume of information on does that expand the market does that make non-smokers turn into smokers no it does not cigarette advertising is used as a competitive weapon between the cigarette companies to divide the market to create brand loyalties and very unfortunately secretary califano has been making all

sort of unfounded and misguided statements particularly about the role of cigarette advertising and he alleges that cigarette advertising is responsible for an increase of smoking among teenage women now in January when the second surgeon general's report was issued secretary califano released a statement a forward to the report criticizing the cigarette companies for brand advertising and for attempting to persuade young people to smoke

Oak we've never done that we believe that smoking is an adult custom it's not for children it's not for teenagers we've had an adults-only policy for many years the cigarette companies have enacted a voluntary code that regulates their advertising in other words the cigarette companies have all agreed voluntarily and they began this long ago 16 years ago when most of today's teenagers were not even born they withdrew all cigarette advertising

from college campuses and college Publications they stopped promotional activity on college campuses they also agreed that they would no longer use celebrities or athletes in any sort of cigarette advertising testimonial they also decided that they would use models of 25 years of age or older and who looked it they've been very aggressive about attempting to avoid the youth Market since the smoking and health controversy is one of the most widely discussed

and the spokesman are frequently confronted with this issue do you agree it's overwhelming do you use dr. richman's term well I'd like to refer if I might to an internal H ew memorandum which turned up in the news media about a year ago which said that reaching scientific consensus could be difficult however because of the controversial nature of several issues involved and I think that statement made little over a year ago is still stands today

then what are you suggesting then in terms of dr. Richmond let's move politics dr. Richmond is a physician is the Surgeon General of the United States his name is on this twelve hundred page report and the government has continued to say this now for all what would be their motives for telling the American people that the that the the evidence is overwhelming that they should quit smoking why would they do that I have no doubt the dr. Richman is sincere in his beliefs and many sincere men and women of science who

who disagree with his judgment I simply think that it's proper for people to hear both sides of it and then make a rational judgment based on the information I'm not here to try to convince anybody to start smoking or discourage anybody from quitting in my view that's your business that's a personal decision and after having received the information you can make that judgment you don't need me or anybody else looking over your shoulder to tell you how to act By the Way You Are

medical doctor and you also have a PhD in what biochemist biochemistry Connie what about this is it is it sophistry to say that okay you haven't proved it because you don't have any control studies where you have 25 people locked up in a room for 25 years and force them to smoke as opposed to 25 other individuals who live exactly the same kind of Life who do not smoke and therefore it can't be proved there is a tremendous difference between statistical

Nations and cause and effect relationships or in other words scientific proof that an agent causes a particular disease statistics lead investigators in One Direction they pose questions they don't answer them additionally in the report made to the Surgeon General in 1964 the scientific advisory panel that had surveyed all of the statistical data said statistical methods are not enough to establish a causal relationship

in any association always 1964 though nothing has changed in terms of what statistics can and can't do we say and indeed this is quite accurate there are some very important unanswered questions and among them why the vast majority of people who smoke over long-duration do not develop the diseases that have been statistically linked to smoking we're talking about lung cancer emphysema heart disease and why not

smokers people who have never touched a tobacco product do develop those diseases not in the same numbers and that's where the statistical correlation is but there may be some other factors Ralph such as genetic predisposition toward disease occupational exposures Geographic locations General lifestyle that may be as important or more important as variables in developing these illnesses which you don't bring them but I would like to find out

sir is this there is a bill before the state legislature that would impose a one son cigarette tax in Pennsylvania's first bill its kind introduced in the United States it would raise 12 million dollars we are the fifth worst state in terms of cancer deaths we are the 45th worst state in terms of dollars raised spent on cancer 263,000 is all we spend I would like to ask and whether or not the tobacco Institute favors passage of this particular legislation that would impose

suppose a 1 cent cigarette tax and have those funds earmarked for cancer control detection and prevention in Pennsylvania for a product that that is the only product in the United States when use legally litter answer the question fine of course I do not think the tobacco industry and speaking personally for myself I would not be in favor of this type of legislation tobacco is already an overburdened tax consumer item in this country is the third highest tax consumer item in this

tree already our federal state and local governments realize six billion dollars a year in profits from the sale of tobacco products so why should we tax smokers more simply because they are enjoying a habit in which they chewed choose to indulge in one side of any story is one side too few the conventional wisdom is challenged on ABC's Good Morning America

yesterday the government released a new report on smoking and health which said that there is no excuse me that there is that there is overwhelming evidence that cigarette smoking causes lung cancer and is a major factor in heart disease the tobacco industry says that there is no repeat no conclusive evidence that smoking causes cancer or heart disease yesterday we discussed this new report with the United States Surgeon General Julius Richmond and John Penny of

education welfare and this morning Bill Dwyer was vice president the tobacco Institute is with us and Steve Bell joins our conversation from Washington good morning mr. Dwyer good morning David thank you very much first of all

the industry naturally tobacco industry wants people to smoke if people if everybody put smoking then there wouldn't be an industry anymore we want them to be able to make a choice use right to make a choice of sure right but if everybody made the choice to quit smoking then of course there wouldn't let say be any more tobacco industry so it's in the interest of the industry to keep people smoking if they're going to continue to make a profit why should the public believe you as opposed to

leaving the Surgeon General and all the doctors in the reports from David I don't think it's quite so much a matter of believing US versus someone else it's believing what the facts are and the facts shouldn't all come from a single Source it isn't really just our statement of contradiction or difference with the Surgeon General there are many independent men and women of science who don't believe that the causal conclusion yet has been reached David we don't deny

why that there is statistical evidence smokers in Greater number than non-smokers do fall victim to these various diseases but we must remember that for example most smokers don't develop lung cancer and certain non-smokers do as well we think it's an open question mr. Dwyer Steve Bell in Washington when you talk though about one source as I understand it you're not talking about One Source you're talking about the government compiling statistics are statistics from some 30,000 different studies done by all types of research people

and the government says that along with the people you site there is still overwhelming evidence Steve the term overwhelming itself represents a judgment there are differing points of view even within the Expressions that are contained in the surgeon general's report but don't you think that there is perhaps a more fundamental question or at least we do and that is warning the Surgeon General has determined there isn't a soul in this country except perhaps a cave dweller who could have

missed that message it's imprinted on the American awareness at that point our position is that individuals ought to be free to choose not children by the way adults they've been put on notice and whether it's aspirin or sweeteners or swordfish or now beer this week as I heard you report Steve or pan-fried hamburgers last summer there are so many incriminated items we think Americans after the information has been passed ought to be able to come to their own conclusion we are not afraid to meet the

all right head on I contacted after I heard you were coming to this area and scheduled you and I called Chicago and talk to the state office Cancer Society and asked them if they would like to send a representative to discuss this issue with you on this program they quickly refused they said and I have no reason to doubt their word as far as they're concerned there is no question of

the relationship between cigarettes and lung cancer cigarettes respire Tori ailments Etc as far as they're concerned it's a closed issue and not open for debate what is your reaction to that that's puzzling because the Cancer Society has participated before with us on programs perhaps this is a switch in tactics on their part perhaps they

is that they are losing out perhaps they believe that we are getting through to the public the public is believing that there is a controversy when in fact there is a controversy all you have to do is look at the Congressional hearings that have been held and see the list of Witnesses on both sides medical and scientific Witnesses some of whom will say we're convinced beyond the shadow of a doubt that smoking causes these things as the American Cancer Society believes and on the other side equally

eminent men and women of science who say we don't know we can't say that for certain and what about non smokers rights I'm a nonsmoker and do I have the right to go to a restaurant or to rat on an airplane where I can't get out and to have to sit there and breathe in somebody's carbon monoxide well first of all tests have shown that the the average person be that person a smoker or nonsmoker can potentially inhale very small amounts of

we're going to promulgate laws on the basis of a health hazard or an alleged health hazard or on the basis of an annoyance and if we're going to do that then we can all run out daily to our legislators and have them in a night some type of law for something that bothers us or annoys us I'm annoyed by screaming babies on airplanes does that mean I should have my legislator enact some law prohibiting children from traveling on airplanes finally Bill demonstrates that once in a while humor can be helpful

none of it has stopped tobacco none of it will stop tobacco the efforts at prohibition are very real the same kinds of things that went on leading up to 1920 and beverage alcohol prohibition are going on now let it be clearly understood our sales are not affected we're selling more cigarettes every year thank you to adults of free choice who either determined to be smokers or not to be smokers all we are asking is a fair break not just for the smokers but for non-smokers

in smokers and all others in this country who want to live their lives making their own decisions not having them made for them by the benevolent bureaucracy of Washington wisdom or these other folks who if you didn't set the temperature of your own bath water and lock the door they'd be in their setting it for you
